Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Complex Analysis and Geometry
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding support to the Conference on Complex Analysis and Geometry to be held on the campus of the University of Wisconsin-Madison on March 27-29, 2015. The conference is devoted to recent developments in several complex variables in connections with fields of harmonic analysis, partial differential equations, conformal geometry, complex geometry, and dynamical systems. It will feature 10 main speakers who are leading mathematicians or junior researchers who have made significant contributions to the fields. There will also be 5 short-talks presented by young researchers who obtained their Ph.D. recently. The conference will create opportunity for exchange of new research results and new frontiers, which will benefit the recent Ph.D.'s and graduate students. The organizers encourage women and members of underrepresented minority groups to participate in the conference, and partial travel support will be provided.

The conference will feature recent research results and methods in several complex variables. The main topics of the conference include the normal form theory in several complex variables and dynamical systems, extension property of biholomorphic mappings, d-bar-Neumann problems, the rigidity and classification of holomorphic mappings between balls, the local and global theory of CR manifolds, Levi-flat hypersurfaces and the lamination theory in complex projective spaces.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Grant DMS 1500302 supported the Conference on Complex Analysis and Geometry, held on the campus of the University of Wisconsin-Madison from March 27 through March 29, 2015. Funds were used to cover travel, lodging, and meals expenses of invited speakers and participants.

Many research interests arise from manifolds, modeled by Euclidean spaces, which carry additional structures in analysis and geometry. The conference covered a wide range of topics in several complex variables, complex geometry, Cauchy-Riemann geometry, and dynamical systems.  For instance, one can study foliation described by vector by solving partial differential equations in several complex variables. A complex structure can arise from a real analytic Riemann manifold via complexification. Domains in complex manifolds, their boundaries, and classifications were the main topics of several talks in the conference.  The invited speakers presented impressive results and they showed how these areas were intricately connected and how research progresses were achieved using methods from different areas.  Some speakers also raised new research problems.

The participants of the conference felt the conference was a success. The organizers advertised the conference through the conference poster and webpage, mailing lists, and other online sources. It also attracted support from the Institute for mathematics and its Applications and the University of Wisconsin-Madison. There were 39 registered participants in addition to a few unregistered participants. The conference supported 14 invited speakers, including two international speakers and several prominent researchers in the fields. Among the participants were 10 graduate students and 8 post-docs and junior researchers.  There were 32 participants who received support in travels, lodging, and meals. 

Besides the formal lectures, the conferences provided young mathematicians the opportunity to meet with experts in the fields to discuss research in informal settings. A few young speakers were actively seeking new employments and the conference was a good opportunity for them to introduce their research to the experts.  

Grant DMS 1500302 supported the Conference on Complex Analysis and Geometry, held on the campus of the University of Wisconsin-Madison from March 27 through March 29, 2015. Funds were used to cover travel, lodging, and meals expenses of invited speakers and participants. 

Last Modified: 02/17/2016
Modified by: Xianghong Gong
